sectionCopy.name: Barriers
sectionCopy.value: There are numerous barriers to renewable energy development in Tajikistan, and market growth beyond the government�s goals remains unlikely. While some policies have been introduced to support the renewables industry, the country does not have a feed-in tariff or auctions program. In addition to Tajikistan�s isolation, there are other barriers such as the high cost of credit and the lack of interest from foreign developers.

sectionCopy.name: Clean energy investment
sectionCopy.value: Tajikistan has not seen any serious investment in renewable energy, with the last deal dating back to 2015. Although the government has called for the construction of small hydro plants and other sources of clean power, no renewables capacity aside from small hydro has come online. The Asian Development Bank approved a $10 million grant in 2013 to support green energy solutions in households, and Pamir Energy, a public-private partnership company, is investing in small hydro projects in rural parts of the country.

sectionCopy.name: Clean energy policy
sectionCopy.value: Tajikistan has little to offer in the way of clean energy policies. While no official renewables target exists, the government aims to have 103MW of small hydro installed by 2020 and, under the SE4All framework, is targeting 10% renewables generation by 2030. To support this goal, the government grants tax exemptions to renewable energy investors. While the small hydro capacity target is within reach, the SE4All remains far off as only 1% of power was generated from renewable energy sources other than large hydro in 2019.

sectionCopy.name: Doing business
sectionCopy.value: Peak power demand has increased moderately in recent years. Despite its near 100% electrification rate, Tajikistan suffers from power reliability issues due to its dependence on large hydropower plants, most of which are operating beyond their intended operating life.

sectionCopy.name: Power market
sectionCopy.value: Barqi Tojik, a vertically integrated state-owned utility, dominates Tajikistan�s power sector. Despite its strong market position, the utility is in poor financial health due to low subsidized tariffs, losses on transmission and distribution services, and mediocre collection rates. The government has granted Pamir Energy the authority to generate power, provide transmission and distribution infrastructure and sell to retail consumers in one remote region, but Barqi Tojik acts as the utility for over 95% of the country�s population. Industrial players consume most of Tajikistan�s power.

sectionCopy.name: Power prices and LCOEs
sectionCopy.value: Tajikistan, like most former Soviet Union countries, has low power prices due to government subsidies. The 2019 average retail price stands at $43/MWh. The government has slightly adjusted rates in recent years in an effort to improve the financial health of its main energy company, Barqi Tojik, but not all tariffs have increased.
